question:
What does HTML stand for?
A. Hyper Text Markup Language
B. Home Tool Markup Language
C. Hyperlinks and Text Markup Language
answer: A. Hyper Text Markup Language - HTML stands for Hyper Text Markup Language, which is the standard markup language for creating web pages.

question:
Who is making the Web standards?
A. Microsoft
B. Mozilla
C. Google
D. The World Wide Web Consortium
answer: D. The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) - The W3C is the international organization that develops web standards.

question:
Correct HTML element for the largest heading:
A. <head>
B. <h1>
C. <h6>
D. <heading>
answer: B. <h1> - The <h1> element is used for the largest heading, while <h6> is the smallest.

question: Correct HTML element for a line break: A. B. C.
answer:
C.
- The
element is a self-closing tag used to create a line break in HTML.

question:
Correct HTML for adding a background color:
A. <background>yellow</background>
B. <body style="background-color:yellow;">
C. <body bg="yellow">
answer: B. <body style="background-color:yellow;"> - Using inline CSS with the style attribute is the correct modern approach. The bg attribute is deprecated.

question:
HTML element to define important text:
A. <i>
B. <strong>
C. <b>
D. <important>
answer: B. <strong> - The <strong> element is used to indicate that its contents have strong importance, seriousness, or urgency.

question:
HTML element for emphasized text:
A. <em>
B. <italic>
C. <i>
answer: A. <em> - The <em> element marks text that has stress emphasis. The <i> element is for italicized text without semantic meaning.

question: Correct HTML for creating a hyperlink: A. http://www.w3schools.com B. W3Schools.com C. W3Schools D. W3Schools.com
answer: C. W3Schools - The href attribute specifies the URL of the page the link goes to.

question:
Which character indicates an end tag?
A. *
B. /
C. ^
D. <
answer: B. / - The forward slash (/) character indicates an end tag in HTML, for example .

question:
Open a link in a new tab?
A. <a href="url" target="new">
B. <a href="url" target="_blank">
C. <a href="url" new>
answer: B. <a href="url" target="_blank"> - The target="_blank" attribute opens the link in a new tab or window.

question:
Which are all <table> elements?
A. <table><tr><td>
B. <table><tr><tt>
C. <thead><body><tr>
D. <table><head><tfoot>
answer: A. <table><tr><td> - <table> creates the table, <tr> creates a table row, and <td> creates a table data cell.

question:
Inline elements start on a new line?
A. True
B. False
answer: B. False - Inline elements do NOT start on a new line. They only take up as much width as necessary. Block elements start on a new line.

question:
How to make a numbered list?
A. <list>
B. <ul>
C. <ol>
D. <dl>
answer: C. <ol> - The <ol> (ordered list) element creates a numbered list. <ul> creates a bulleted list.

question:
How to make a bulleted list?
A. <ol>
B. <dl>
C. <list>
D. <ul>
answer: D. <ul> - The <ul> (unordered list) element creates a bulleted list.

question:
Correct HTML for a checkbox:
A. <input type="checkbox">
B. <check>
C. <input type="check">
D. <checkbox>
answer: A. <input type="checkbox"> - The input element with type="checkbox" creates a checkbox.

question:
Correct HTML for a text input field:
A. <textinput type="text">
B. <input type="textfield">
C. <textfield>
D. <input type="text">
answer: D. <input type="text"> - The input element with type="text" creates a single-line text input field.

question:
Correct HTML for a drop-down list:
A. <input type="dropdown">
B. <list>
C. <select>
D. <input type="list">
answer: C. <select> - The <select> element creates a drop-down list. It contains <option> elements for each choice.

question:
Correct HTML for a text area:
A. <input type="textbox">
B. <input type="textarea">
C. <textarea>
answer: C. <textarea> - The <textarea> element creates a multi-line text input control.

question: Correct HTML for inserting an image: A. image.gif B. C. D.
answer: B. - The element uses the src attribute for the image source and alt for alternative text. It's a self-closing tag.

question:
Correct HTML for a background image:
A. <body style="background-image:url(background.gif)">
B. <body bg="background.gif">
C. <background img="background.gif">
answer: A. <body style="background-image:url(background.gif)"> - Using inline CSS with background-image is the correct modern approach. The bg attribute is deprecated.

question:
An <iframe> is used to display a webpage within a webpage.
A. True
B. False
C. There is no such thing as <iframe>
answer: A. True - The <iframe> (inline frame) element embeds another HTML page within the current page.

question:
HTML comments start with <!-- and end with -->
A. True
B. False
answer: A. True - HTML comments use <!-- to start and --> to end. Comments are not displayed in the browser.

question:
Block elements are normally displayed without starting a new line.
A. True
B. False
answer: B. False - Block elements DO start on a new line and take up the full width available. Inline elements don't start on a new line.

question:
Which element defines the title of a document?
A. <head>
B. <title>
C. <meta>
answer: B. <title> - The <title> element defines the title of the document, which appears in the browser's title bar or tab.

question:
Which attribute specifies alternate text for an image?
A. alt
B. longdesc
C. src
D. title
answer: A. alt - The alt attribute provides alternative text for an image, used by screen readers and when the image cannot be displayed.

question:
Correct doctype for HTML5:
A. Long W3C doctype
B. <!DOCTYPE HTML5>
C. <!DOCTYPE html>
answer: C. <!DOCTYPE html> - HTML5 uses the simple <!DOCTYPE html> declaration, which is case-insensitive.

question:
Which element specifies a footer?
A. <footer>
B. <bottom>
C. <section>
answer: A. <footer> - The <footer> element represents a footer for its nearest sectioning content or sectioning root element.

question:
Can you embed SVG into HTML?
A. True
B. False
answer: A. True - SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) can be embedded directly into HTML using the <svg> element or as an external file.

question:
Correct element for video:
A. <movie>
B. <video>
C. <media>
answer: B. <video> - The <video> element is used to embed video content in an HTML document.

question:
Correct element for audio:
A. <audio>
B. <mp3>
C. <sound>
answer: A. <audio> - The <audio> element is used to embed sound content in an HTML document.

question:
What is contenteditable used for?
A. Defines context menu
B. Updates content from server
C. Finds content in strings
D. Makes content editable
answer: D. Makes content editable - The contenteditable attribute makes an element's content editable by the user.

question:
onblur and onfocus are:
A. HTML elements
B. Style attributes
C. Event attributes
answer: C. Event attributes - onblur and onfocus are event attributes that trigger JavaScript when an element loses or gains focus.

question:
SVG graphics are in what format?
A. XML
B. HTML
C. CSS
answer: A. XML - SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) is an XML-based vector image format.

question:
The <canvas> element is used to:
A. Display database records
B. Manipulate MySQL data
C. Create draggable elements
D. Draw graphics
answer: D. Draw graphics - The <canvas> element is used to draw graphics via JavaScript, such as charts, games, or animations.

question:
Attribute that requires an input field:
A. placeholder
B. validate
C. formvalidate
D. required
answer: D. required - The required attribute specifies that an input field must be filled out before submitting the form.

question:
Input type for a slider:
A. slider
B. range
C. search
D. controls
answer: B. range - The input type="range" creates a slider control for selecting a numeric value within a range.

question:
HTML element for scalar measurement:
A. <gauge>
B. <measure>
C. <range>
D. <meter>
answer: D. <meter> - The <meter> element represents a scalar measurement within a known range, like disk usage or a score.

question:
Element that defines navigation links:
A. <navigate>
B. <nav>
C. <navigation>
answer: B. <nav> - The <nav> element represents a section of a page whose purpose is to provide navigation links.

question:
What does <aside> define?
A. ASCII character set
B. Left-side navigation
C. Content aside from main content
answer: C. Content aside from main content - The <aside> element represents a portion of a document whose content is only indirectly related to the main content.

question:
Element that defines a header:
A. <header>
B. <head>
C. <section>
D. <top>
answer: A. <header> - The <header> element represents introductory content, typically a group of introductory or navigational aids.

question:
What does CSS stand for?
A. Cascading Style Sheets
B. Computer Style Sheets
C. Colorful Style Sheets
D. Creative Style Sheets
answer: A. Cascading Style Sheets - CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets, which is used to style and layout web pages.

question:
What is the correct HTML for referring to an external style sheet?
A. <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="mystyle.css">
B. <style src="mystyle.css">
C. <stylesheet>mystyle.css</stylesheet>
answer: A. <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="mystyle.css"> - The <link> element with rel="stylesheet" is used to link external CSS files.

question:
Where in an HTML document is the correct place to refer to an external style sheet?
A. In the <body> section
B. At the end of the document
C. In the <head> section
answer: C. In the <head> section - External style sheets should be referenced in the <head> section of the HTML document for proper loading order.

question:
Which HTML tag is used to define an internal style sheet?
A. <style>
B. <css>
C. <script>
answer: A. <style> - The <style> tag is used to define internal (embedded) CSS styles within an HTML document.

question:
Which HTML attribute is used to define inline styles?
A. font
B. class
C. styles
D. style
answer: D. style - The style attribute is used to apply inline CSS styles directly to an HTML element.
B. body {color: black;} - CSS syntax uses selectors followed by curly braces containing property-value pairs separated by colons.

question:
How do you insert a comment in a CSS file?
A. // this is a comment
B. /* this is a comment */
C. // this is a comment //
D. ' this is a comment
answer: B. /* this is a comment */ - CSS comments use /* to start and */ to end. They can span multiple lines.

question:
Which property is used to change the background color?
A. bgcolor
B. background-color
C. color
answer: B. background-color - The background-color property sets the background color of an element. The color property changes text color.
C. h1 {background-color:#FFFFFF;} - To style all elements of a type, use the element selector directly without any additional qualifiers.

question:
Which CSS property changes the text color?
A. text-color
B. color
C. fgcolor
answer: B. color - The color property sets the foreground color (text color) of an element.

question:
Which CSS property controls the text size?
A. font-size
B. font-style
C. text-size
D. text-style
answer: A. font-size - The font-size property controls the size of the text. font-style controls italic/oblique, not size.

C. p {font-weight:bold;} - The font-weight property with value bold makes text bold. This is the correct CSS syntax for styling all

elements.
B. a {text-decoration:none;} - The text-decoration property with value none removes underlines and other text decorations.

question:
How do you make each word start with a capital letter?
A. text-style:capitalize
B. transform:capitalize
C. text-transform:capitalize
D. You can't do that with CSS
answer: C. text-transform:capitalize - The text-transform property with value capitalize makes the first letter of each word uppercase.

question:
Which property changes the font of an element?
A. font-style
B. font-weight
C. font-family
answer: C. font-family - The font-family property specifies the font family (typeface) for text. font-style changes italic/oblique, font-weight changes boldness.
C. font-weight:bold; - The font-weight property with value bold makes text bold. You can also use numeric values like 700.
D. border-width:10px 1px 5px 20px; - When using shorthand with 4 values, the order is top, right, bottom, left (clockwise).

question:
Which property changes the left margin?
A. padding-left
B. margin-left
C. indent
answer: B. margin-left - The margin-left property sets the left margin of an element. padding-left sets padding, not margin.

question:
Can you use negative values for padding?
A. Yes
B. No
answer: B. No - Padding cannot have negative values. Margins can have negative values, but padding cannot.
B. list-style-type: square; - The list-style-type property with value square makes list items display with square bullets.

question:
How do you select an element with id demo?
A. *demo
B. demo
C. .demo
D. #demo
answer: D. #demo - The hash (#) symbol is used to select elements by their id attribute in CSS.

question:
How do you select elements with class test?
A. .test
B. *test
C. #test
D. test
answer: A. .test - The dot (.) symbol is used to select elements by their class attribute in CSS.

question:
How do you select all

elements inside a

? A. div + p B. div p C. div.p
answer:
B. div p - The space (descendant selector) selects all

elements that are descendants of

elements. div + p is the adjacent sibling selector.

question:
How do you group selectors?
A. Separate each selector with a space
B. Separate each selector with a comma
C. Separate each selector with a plus sign
answer: B. Separate each selector with a comma - Multiple selectors can be grouped together using commas to apply the same styles to different elements.

question:
What is the default value of the position property?
A. relative
B. fixed
C. absolute
D. static
answer: D. static - The default value of the position property is static, which means the element follows the normal document flow.

question:
Inside which HTML element do we put the JavaScript?
A. <scripting>
B. <script>
C. <javascript>
D. <js>
answer: B. <script> - JavaScript code is placed inside the <script> element in HTML.
A. document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = "Hello World!"; - getElementById() is the correct method to select an element by its id, and innerHTML is used to change the content.

question:
Where is the correct place to insert JavaScript?
A. The <head> section
B. The <body> section
C. Both the <head> and <body> sections
answer: C. Both the <head> and <body> sections - JavaScript can be placed in either the <head> or <body> section, or both, depending on when you want the script to execute.

question:
Correct syntax for referring to an external script named "xxx.js":
A. <script src="xxx.js">
B. <script href="xxx.js">
C. <script name="xxx.js">
answer: A. <script src="xxx.js"> - The src attribute is used to specify the URL of an external JavaScript file. href is used for links, not scripts.

question:
The external JavaScript file must contain the <script> tag.
A. True
B. False
answer: B. False - External JavaScript files should contain only JavaScript code, not HTML tags like <script>. The <script> tag is only used in the HTML file that references the external script.
C. alert("Hello World"); - The alert() function displays an alert dialog with the specified message.

question:
How do you create a function in JavaScript?
A. function myFunction()
B. function:myFunction()
C. function = myFunction()
answer: A. function myFunction() - Functions are declared using the function keyword followed by the function name and parentheses.

question:
How do you call a function named "myFunction"?
A. call myFunction()
B. myFunction()
C. call function myFunction()
answer: B. myFunction() - To call a function, simply write the function name followed by parentheses.

question:
How do you write an IF statement in JavaScript?
A. if i = 5 then
B. if (i == 5)
C. if i == 5 then
D. if i = 5
answer: B. if (i == 5) - JavaScript if statements use parentheses around the condition. == is used for comparison, = is for assignment.

question:
IF statement for "i is NOT equal to 5":
A. if i =! 5 then
B. if (i != 5)
C. if i <> 5
D. if (i <> 5)
answer: B. if (i != 5) - The != operator means "not equal to". The condition must be in parentheses.

question:
How does a WHILE loop start?
A. while (i <= 10; i++)
B. while i = 1 to 10
C. while (i <= 10)
answer: C. while (i <= 10) - A while loop starts with the while keyword followed by a condition in parentheses. The increment (i++) goes inside the loop body, not in the condition.

question:
How does a FOR loop start?
A. for (i <= 5; i++)
B. for (i = 0; i <= 5; i++)
C. for (i = 0; i <= 5)
D. for i = 1 to 5
answer: B. for (i = 0; i <= 5; i++) - A for loop has three parts: initialization (i = 0), condition (i <= 5), and increment (i++), all separated by semicolons.

question:
How do you add a comment in JavaScript?
A. //This is a comment
B. <!--This is a comment-->
C. 'This is a comment
answer: A. //This is a comment - Single-line comments in JavaScript use //. <!-- --> is HTML comment syntax, not JavaScript.

question:
How do you insert a multi-line comment?
A. /* This comment has
 more than one line */
B. <!-- This comment has more than one line -->
C. // This comment has
 more than one line //
answer:
A. /* This comment has
 more than one line */ - Multi-line comments in JavaScript use /* to start and */ to end.

question:
Correct way to write a JavaScript array:
A. var colors = 1 = ("red"), 2 = ("green"), 3 = ("blue")
B. var colors = "red", "green", "blue"
C. var colors = ["red", "green", "blue"]
D. var colors = (1:"red", 2:"green", 3:"blue")
answer: C. var colors = ["red", "green", "blue"] - Arrays in JavaScript are created using square brackets [] with elements separated by commas.

question:
How do you round 7.25 to the nearest integer?
A. round(7.25)
B. Math.round(7.25)
C. rnd(7.25)
D. Math.rnd(7.25)
answer: B. Math.round(7.25) - The Math.round() method rounds a number to the nearest integer. Math is a built-in object that provides mathematical functions.

question:
How do you find the highest value between x and y?
A. Math.max(x, y)
B. ceil(x, y)
C. top(x, y)
D. Math.ceil(x, y)
answer: A. Math.max(x, y) - Math.max() returns the largest of the given numbers. Math.ceil() rounds up to the nearest integer, but doesn't compare two values.
B. w2 = window.open("http://www.w3schools.com"); - The window.open() method opens a new browser window or tab. There is no window.new() method.

question:
JavaScript is the same as Java.
A. True
B. False
answer: B. False - JavaScript and Java are completely different programming languages. JavaScript was originally named to capitalize on Java's popularity, but they are unrelated.

question:
Which is NOT a legal variable declaration keyword?
A. constant
B. var
C. let
answer: A. constant - The correct keyword is const (not constant). var and let are both valid keywords for declaring variables in JavaScript.

question:
Which event occurs when the user clicks an element?
A. onmouseclick
B. onclick
C. onmouseover
D. onchange
answer: B. onclick - The onclick event occurs when a user clicks on an element. onmouseover occurs when the mouse moves over an element, and onchange occurs when the value of an element changes.
C. var carName; - Variables in JavaScript are declared using var, let, or const keywords. 'v' and 'variable' are not valid keywords.

question:
Which operator assigns a value to a variable?
A. x
B. -
C. =
D. *
answer: C. = - The assignment operator (=) is used to assign a value to a variable. * is multiplication, - is subtraction.

question:
Boolean(10 > 9) returns:
A. NaN
B. false
C. true
answer: C. true - The expression 10 > 9 evaluates to true because 10 is greater than 9. Boolean() converts the result to a boolean value.

question:
Is JavaScript case-sensitive?
A. No
B. Yes
answer: B. Yes - JavaScript is case-sensitive. This means that variables, function names, and keywords must be written with consistent capitalization.

question:
Bootstrap 3 is mobile-first.
A. True
B. False
answer: A. True - Bootstrap 3 is designed with a mobile-first approach, meaning it's optimized for mobile devices first, then scales up for larger screens.

question:
Which class provides a responsive fixed-width container?
A. .container
B. .container-fixed
C. .container-fluid
answer: A. .container - The .container class provides a responsive fixed-width container that adapts to different screen sizes.

question:
Which class provides a full-width container spanning the entire viewport?
A. .container
B. .container-fixed
C. .container-fluid
answer: C. .container-fluid - The .container-fluid class provides a full-width container that spans the entire width of the viewport.

question:
The Bootstrap grid system is based on how many columns?
A. 3
B. 12
C. 6
D. 9
answer: B. 12 - The Bootstrap grid system is based on a 12-column layout, which allows for flexible and responsive page layouts.

question:
Which class adds zebra-stripes to a table?
A. .even and .odd
B. .table-bordered
C. .table-striped
D. .table-zebra
answer: C. .table-striped - The .table-striped class adds zebra-striping (alternating row colors) to any table row within the <tbody>.

question:
Which class shapes an image to a circle?
A. .img-rounded
B. .img-thumbnail
C. .img-circle
D. .img-round
answer: C. .img-circle - The .img-circle class shapes images into circles. .img-rounded adds rounded corners, and .img-thumbnail creates a thumbnail.

question:
Which class is used to create a big box that calls attention?
A. .bigbox
B. .container
C. .jumbotron
answer: C. .jumbotron - The .jumbotron class creates a big box for calling extra attention to featured content or information.

question:
Which button class is used to create a large button?
A. .btn-large
B. .btn-l
C. .btn-lg
D. .btn-xl
answer: C. .btn-lg - The .btn-lg class creates a large button. Bootstrap also provides .btn-sm for small buttons and .btn-xs for extra small buttons.

question:
Which class is used to create a button group?
A. .group-button
B. .group-btn
C. .btn-group
D. .button-group
answer: C. .btn-group - The .btn-group class groups a series of buttons together on a single line, which is useful for toolbar-like presentations.

question: How do you insert a search icon? A. B. C. D.
answer: D. - Bootstrap's Glyphicons require both the base .glyphicon class and the specific icon class (e.g., .glyphicon-search).

question:
Which class is used to create a badge?
A. .flag
B. .tag
C. .badge
D. .label
answer: C. .badge - The .badge class is used to create badges, which are small labels used to highlight new or unread items.

question:
Which class is used to create basic pagination?
A. .page
B. .navigation
C. .pages
D. .pagination
answer: D. .pagination - The .pagination class is used to create pagination links, which are useful for splitting content across multiple pages.

question:
Which class is used to create a basic list group?
A. .list-group
B. .grouped-list
C. .group-list
answer: A. .list-group - The .list-group class is used to create a list of items. List groups are a flexible and powerful component for displaying lists of content.

question:
Which class adds a heading to a panel?
A. .panel-head
B. .panel-footer
C. .panel-header
D. .panel-heading
answer: D. .panel-heading - The .panel-heading class adds a heading to a panel. Bootstrap panels also use .panel-body for the main content and .panel-footer for the footer.

question:
Which class indicates a dropdown menu?
A. .dropdown-list
B. .select
C. .dropdown
answer: C. .dropdown - The .dropdown class is used to create a dropdown menu. It requires the .dropdown-menu class for the actual dropdown content.

question:
A standard navigation tab is created with:
A. <ul class="nav tabs">
B. <ul class="navigation-tabs">
C. <ul class="nav nav-tabs">
D. <ul class="nav nav-navbar">
answer: C. <ul class="nav nav-tabs"> - Navigation tabs are created using both the .nav base class and the .nav-tabs modifier class.

question:
A standard navigation bar is created with:
A. <nav class="nav navbar">
B. <nav class="navbar navbar-default">
C. <nav class="navigationbar navbar-default">
D. <nav class="navbar default-navbar">
answer: B. <nav class="navbar navbar-default"> - A standard navigation bar uses the .navbar base class along with .navbar-default for the default styling.

question:
Which class is used to create a black navigation bar?
A. .navbar-black
B. .navbar-dark
C. .navbar-inverse
D. .navbar-default
answer: C. .navbar-inverse - The .navbar-inverse class creates a black/dark navigation bar. In Bootstrap 4+, this was replaced with .navbar-dark.

question:
Which plugin cycles through elements like a slideshow?
A. Orbit
B. Scrollspy
C. Slideshow
D. Carousel
answer: D. Carousel - The Carousel plugin is a slideshow component for cycling through elements, images, or slides of text.

question:
Which plugin is used to create a modal window?
A. Window
B. Modal
C. Dialog Box
D. Popup
answer: B. Modal - The Modal plugin creates a dialog box/popup window that is displayed on top of the current page.

question:
Which plugin is used to create a tooltip?
A. Tooltip
B. Popup
C. Dialog Box
D. Modal
answer: A. Tooltip - The Tooltip plugin creates small pop-up boxes that appear when the user moves the mouse pointer over an element.

question:
Which contextual class indicates a successful or positive action?
A. .text-info
B. .text-primary
C. .text-success
D. .text-warning
answer: C. .text-success - The .text-success class indicates a successful or positive action. Bootstrap provides contextual classes for different semantic meanings.

question:
Which contextual class indicates a dangerous or negative action?
A. .text-info
B. .text-danger
C. .text-primary
D. .text-warning
answer: B. .text-danger - The .text-danger class indicates a dangerous or potentially negative action, typically displayed in red.

question:
Which class indicates uppercased text?
A. .uppercase
B. .text-capitalize
C. .ucase
D. .text-uppercase
answer: D. .text-uppercase - The .text-uppercase class transforms text to uppercase. Bootstrap also provides .text-lowercase and .text-capitalize.

question:
The Bootstrap grid system works across multiple devices.
A. False
B. True
answer: B. True - The Bootstrap grid system is responsive and works across multiple devices and screen sizes, from mobile phones to large desktop screens.

question:
What is React?
A. React is a programming language.
B. React is a database engine.
C. React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces.
answer: C. React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces - React is a popular JavaScript library developed by Facebook for building interactive user interfaces, particularly for web applications.

question:
What does my-react-app refer to in the command?
 npm create vite@latest my-react-app -- --template react
A. The name you want to use for the new app
B. The type of app to create
C. A reference to an existing app
answer: A. The name you want to use for the new app - In the command, 'my-react-app' is the name you choose for your new React application. You can replace it with any name you prefer.

question:
What command starts the React development server?
A. npm run dev
B. npm start
C. npm build
D. npm serve
answer: A. npm run dev - When using Vite, the command 'npm run dev' starts the development server. For Create React App, it would be 'npm start'.

question:
Default localhost port that Vite uses:
A. 5000
B. 3000
C. 8080
D. 5173
answer: D. 5173 - Vite uses port 5173 by default for the development server. Create React App uses port 3000 by default.

question:
To develop and run React code, Node.js is required.
A. False
B. True
answer: B. True - Node.js is required to run React development tools, package managers (npm/yarn), and the development server. React applications need Node.js to be installed.
D. h1 - The Car component returns an <h1> element, so when rendered, an <h1> element will be displayed in the DOM. The component itself is just a function that returns JSX.

question:
What is the children prop?
A. A property that lets you set an object as a property
B. A property that lets you pass data to child components
C. A property that adds child values to state
D. A property that lets you nest components inside other components
answer: D. A property that lets you nest components inside other components - The children prop is a special prop that allows you to pass content between component tags, enabling component composition.

question:
Which keyword creates a constant?
A. constant
B. const
C. let
D. var
answer: B. const - The const keyword creates a constant variable that cannot be reassigned. let creates a block-scoped variable, and var creates a function-scoped variable.

question:
A copy of the real DOM that is kept in memory is called:
A. Shadow DOM
B. DOM
C. Virtual DOM
D. React DOM
answer: C. Virtual DOM - React uses a Virtual DOM, which is a lightweight copy of the real DOM kept in memory. React compares the Virtual DOM with the real DOM to efficiently update only what changed.

question:
React component names must begin with an uppercase letter.
A. True
B. False
answer: A. True - React component names must start with an uppercase letter. Lowercase names are treated as HTML elements, while uppercase names are treated as React components.

question:
Which operator is used for conditional rendering?
A. ??
B. ||
C. ::
D. &&
answer: D. && - The && (logical AND) operator is commonly used for conditional rendering in React. If the condition is true, it renders the element; if false, it renders nothing.

question:
When rendering a list using map(), what is required?
A. index
B. key
C. data
D. id
answer: B. key - When rendering lists in React, each element must have a unique 'key' prop. This helps React identify which items have changed, been added, or removed for efficient updates.

question:
What does JSX stand for?
A. JavaScript Extreme
B. JavaScript XML
C. JavaScript Expressions
D. JavaScript X-factor
answer: B. JavaScript XML - JSX stands for JavaScript XML. It's a syntax extension that allows you to write HTML-like code in JavaScript, which React then transforms into JavaScript.

question:
How can you optimize performance for a component that always renders the same?
A. Use the useMemo Hook.
B. Use the useReducer Hook.
C. Wrap it in React.memo
D. Use shouldComponentUpdate
answer: C. Wrap it in React.memo - React.memo is a higher-order component that memoizes the result, preventing unnecessary re-renders when props haven't changed. This is useful for function components.

question:
What props will be available here?
<Car {...props} />
A. all of them
B. children
C. only static ones
D. only updated ones
answer: A. all of them - The spread operator {...props} passes all properties from the props object to the Car component. This is a convenient way to pass multiple props at once.

question:
What is a common use case for ref?
A. To refer to a function
B. To bind the function
C. To directly access a DOM node
D. To refer to another JavaScript file
answer: C. To directly access a DOM node - Refs provide a way to access DOM nodes or React elements directly. Common use cases include focusing inputs, measuring elements, or integrating with third-party DOM libraries.
D. const combined = [...array1, ...array2]; - The spread operator (...) expands arrays into individual elements. [...array1, ...array2] creates a new array containing all elements from both arrays.

question:
React can only render elements inside the root element.
A. True
B. False
answer: B. False - While React typically renders into a single root element, you can have multiple root elements using React 18's createRoot. However, each component can only return a single root element (or use fragments).
B. export default Car; - The 'export default' syntax allows you to export a component as the default export, which can then be imported without curly braces in other files.

D. The function must start with a capital letter - React component names must start with an uppercase letter. 'car' should be 'Car'. Lowercase names are treated as HTML elements, not React components.

question:
How are components combined to create a UI?
A. With code splitting
B. By nesting components
C. By putting them in a folder
D. With webpack
answer: B. By nesting components - Components are combined by nesting them inside other components. This composition allows you to build complex UIs from simple, reusable pieces.

question:
React Hooks replace class components, but classes will stay in React.
A. False
B. True
answer: B. True - React Hooks provide a way to use state and other React features in function components, but class components are still supported and will remain in React for backward compatibility.

question:
Which is NOT a rule of Hooks?
A. Hooks cannot be conditional
B. Hooks can only be called inside Function components
C. Hooks can be called in Class or Function components
D. Hooks can only be called at the top level
answer: C. Hooks can be called in Class or Function components - Hooks can ONLY be called in Function components, not in Class components. This is one of the fundamental rules of Hooks.

B. {make: 'Ford', model: 'Mustang'} - This uses ES6 shorthand property syntax. When the property name and variable name are the same, you can use { make, model } instead of { make: make, model: model }.

question:
Why should you avoid copying prop values into state?
A. Because props cannot be stored in state
B. Because it creates two versions of the same state that can get out of sync
C. Because data must flow up to the parent
D. Because you should never mutate state
answer: B. Because it creates two versions of the same state that can get out of sync - Copying props into state creates a duplicate source of truth. If props change, the state won't update automatically, leading to inconsistencies. Use props directly or derive state from props when needed.

question:
What is the correct syntax for creating a Django project?
A. django-admin startproject my_tennis_club
B. django start my_tennis_club
C. py manage.py start-django my_tennis_club
answer: A. django-admin startproject my_tennis_club - The django-admin startproject command creates a new Django project with the specified name. This is the standard way to initialize a new Django project.

question:
Correct syntax to start the Django development server:
A. py manage.py startserver
B. py manage.py runserver
C. py manage.py run
answer: B. py manage.py runserver - The runserver command starts Django's development server. On Unix/Mac, you would use 'python manage.py runserver' instead of 'py'.

question:
Which file is NOT part of a new Django project?
A. templates.py
B. manage.py
C. settings.py
answer: A. templates.py - templates.py is not a standard Django file. manage.py is the command-line utility, and settings.py contains project settings. Templates are typically stored in a 'templates' directory, not a .py file.

question:
Which language is Django written in?
A. Java
B. C
C. Python
answer: C. Python - Django is a high-level Python web framework that encourages rapid development and clean, pragmatic design.

question:
Incoming requests are handled in which file?
A. settings.py
B. urls.py
C. manage.py
answer: B. urls.py - The urls.py file contains URL patterns that map URLs to views. This is where Django routes incoming requests to the appropriate view functions.

question:
Incoming requests are redirected to functions called:
A. controls
B. models
C. views
answer: C. views - In Django's MVC-like architecture, views are Python functions (or classes) that handle requests and return responses. They contain the business logic for processing requests.

question:
Django templates are often .html pages.
A. Yes
B. No, never
answer: A. Yes - Django templates are typically HTML files that can contain Django template language syntax. They're stored in a 'templates' directory and have .html extensions.

question:
In Django, data is created in objects called:
A. Tables
B. Models
C. SQLite
answer: B. Models - Models in Django are Python classes that define the structure of your database tables. Each model maps to a database table, and model attributes map to table columns.

question:
After changing a model, which command must you run?
A. py manage.py executemigrations
B. py manage.py makemigrations
C. py manage.py runmigrations
answer: B. py manage.py makemigrations - After modifying models, you must run makemigrations to create migration files that describe the changes. Then run migrate to apply them to the database.

question:
Correct syntax to import a model named Member from app members:
A. import Member from members
B. import members.Member
C. from members.models import Member
answer: C. from members.models import Member - In Django, models are typically stored in a models.py file within each app. The correct import syntax follows Python's module import pattern.

question:
Correct way to use a Django variable named firstname in a template:
A. '' firstname ''
B. ## firstname ##
C. {{ firstname }}
answer: C. {{ firstname }} - Django template variables are enclosed in double curly braces {{ }}. This syntax outputs the value of the variable in the template.

question:
In Django, views are written as:
A. Python tuples
B. Python functions
C. Python dictionaries
answer: B. Python functions - Django views are typically written as Python functions (or classes) that take a request object and return an HttpResponse. Function-based views are the most common approach.

question:
The configuration file for Django installation is:
A. config.py
B. settings.py
C. views.py
answer: B. settings.py - The settings.py file contains all the configuration for your Django project, including database settings, installed apps, middleware, templates, and more.

question:
Correct syntax to turn off debugging:
A. DEBUG : 0
B. DEBUG = False
C. DEBUG = 'OFF'
D. DEBUG : 'off'
answer: B. DEBUG = False - In settings.py, DEBUG is a boolean variable. Set it to False to turn off debugging mode, which is essential for production deployments.

question:
When debugging is off, you must define allowed hosts.
A. False
B. True
answer: B. True - When DEBUG = False, Django requires you to set ALLOWED_HOSTS in settings.py. This is a security measure that specifies which host/domain names your Django site can serve.

question:
Correct syntax to create a superuser for the admin interface:
A. py manage.py createuser
B. py manage.py createsuperuser
C. py.manage.py createadminuser
answer: B. py manage.py createsuperuser - The createsuperuser command creates an admin user with full permissions to access Django's admin interface.

question:
A model must be registered in which file to appear in admin?
A. settings.py
B. admin.py
C. views.py
answer: B. admin.py - Models must be registered in the admin.py file using admin.site.register() to appear in Django's admin interface.
C. {% for x in y %} - Django template tags use {% %} syntax. The for loop tag iterates over a sequence, similar to Python's for loop.

question:
Correct Django tag for writing a comment:
A. remove
B. exclude
C. comment
answer: C. comment - The {% comment %} tag allows you to write comments in Django templates that won't be rendered in the final HTML output.

question:
Correct Django tag for writing an if statement:
A. if
B. when
C. !!
answer: A. if - The {% if %} tag is used for conditional rendering in Django templates, similar to Python's if statement.

question:
Correct tag to end an if statement:
A. end
B. end if
C. endif
D. /if
answer: C. endif - Django template tags that require closing use {% endif %} to close an {% if %} statement. This follows the pattern of {% tag %} ... {% endtag %}.

question:
Correct equality operator in an if statement:
A. if A equal B
B. if A == B
C. if A like B
answer: B. if A == B - Django templates use == for equality comparison, just like Python. The == operator checks if two values are equal.

question:
Tag used to create a variable inside a template:
A. with
B. var
C. let
answer: A. with - The {% with %} tag allows you to create a variable within a template block. It's useful for caching complex expressions or creating temporary variables.

question:
Correct syntax to return only records where firstname is "Emil":
A. where(firstname LIKE 'Emil')
B. filter(firstname='Emil')
C. get(firstname='Emil')
answer: B. filter(firstname='Emil') - The filter() method returns a QuerySet containing objects that match the given lookup parameters. get() returns a single object and raises an exception if multiple or no objects are found.

question:
Correct syntax to sort a queryset alphabetically by firstname:
A. sort('firstname')
B. order_by('firstname')
C. sortby('firstname')
D. orderby('firstname')
answer: B. order_by('firstname') - The order_by() method sorts a QuerySet by the specified field(s). Use '-firstname' for descending order.

question:
What Git command is used to create a new local repository?
A. git start
B. git init
C. git create
D. git new
answer: B. git init - The 'git init' command initializes a new Git repository in the current directory, creating a .git folder that tracks all changes.

question:
Which command downloads a repository from GitHub?
A. git download
B. git clone
C. git fetch
D. git pull
answer: B. git clone - The 'git clone' command creates a copy of a remote repository on your local machine, including all files and commit history.

question:
Purpose of .gitignore?
A. List contributors
B. Specify files Git should ignore
C. Define GitHub Actions
D. Store Git config
answer: B. Specify files Git should ignore - The .gitignore file tells Git which files and directories to ignore, preventing them from being tracked or committed.

question:
Correct TDD sequence?
A. Write code  write tests  refactor
B. Design tests  write code  test
C. Write tests  write code  refactor
D. Design architecture  write tests  implement
answer: C. Write tests  write code  refactor - Test-Driven Development (TDD) follows the Red-Green-Refactor cycle: write failing tests first, then write code to pass, then refactor.

question:
Unit tests
A. Test entire app
B. Test individual components in isolation
C. Only test UI
D. Require a production DB
answer: B. Test individual components in isolation - Unit tests verify that individual functions, methods, or components work correctly in isolation, without dependencies on other parts of the system.

question:
Select all columns from "users":
A. SELECT users
B. SELECT ALL FROM users
C. SELECT * FROM users
D. SELECT COLUMNS FROM users
answer: C. SELECT * FROM users - The asterisk (*) is a wildcard that selects all columns from the specified table.

question:
SQL command to add a new record:
A. ADD
B. INSERT
C. APPEND
D. CREATE
answer: B. INSERT - The INSERT statement adds new rows of data to a table in the database.

question:
REST stands for:
A. Reactive State Transfer
B. Representational State Transfer
C. Resource Standard Transfer
D. Remote Execution Service Tech
answer: B. Representational State Transfer - REST is an architectural style for designing networked applications, using standard HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE).

question:
Successful status code:
A. 200
B. 404
C. 500
D. 302
answer: A. 200 - HTTP status code 200 indicates a successful request. 404 is Not Found, 500 is Server Error, and 302 is a redirect.
B. {"name": "John", "age": 30} - JSON requires property names to be in double quotes, and uses colons (:) to separate keys from values, not equals signs.

question:
Purpose of a linter?
A. Optimize performance
B. Identify coding errors/style issues
C. Compile code
D. Manage dependencies
answer: B. Identify coding errors/style issues - Linters analyze code to find potential errors, enforce coding standards, and suggest improvements for code quality and consistency.

question:
Main purpose of a precommit hook?
A. Auto-commit changes
B. Run tests/linters before commit
C. Create branch for each commit
D. Sync with remote
answer: B. Run tests/linters before commit - Pre-commit hooks automatically run scripts (like tests or linters) before a commit is finalized, helping catch issues early.

question:
Define an unordered list:
A. <ol>
B. <ul>
C. <list>
D. <dl>
answer: B. <ul> - The <ul> (unordered list) element creates a bulleted list. <ol> creates an ordered (numbered) list, and <dl> creates a description list.

question:
Purpose of <meta> tag?
A. Displays metadata to users
B. Provides metadata about HTML doc
C. Creates animations
D. Links JS files
answer: B. Provides metadata about HTML doc - The <meta> tag provides metadata about the HTML document, such as character encoding, viewport settings, and page description for search engines.

question:
HTML5 standalone content element:
A. <div>
B. <span>
C. <article>
D. <content>
answer: C. <article> - The <article> element represents a standalone, self-contained piece of content. <div> and <span> are generic containers without semantic meaning.

question:
Purpose of <form>?
A. Create formatted text
B. Collect user input
C. Import HTML files
D. Define footer
answer: B. Collect user input - The <form> element is used to create an HTML form for collecting user input, which can be submitted to a server for processing.

question: Required attribute: A. title B. src C. alt D. width
answer: B. src - The src attribute is required and specifies the path to the image file. While alt is highly recommended for accessibility, src is the only required attribute.

question:
Purpose of <!DOCTYPE>:
A. Declares document as HTML
B. Links to external doctype
C. Tells browser what HTML version used
D. Creates a variable
answer: C. Tells browser what HTML version used - The <!DOCTYPE> declaration tells the browser which version of HTML the document is using, ensuring proper rendering.

question:
CSS stands for:
A. Computer Style Sheets
B. Creative Style System
C. Cascading Style Sheets
D. Colorful Style Sheets
answer: C. Cascading Style Sheets - CSS is used to style and layout web pages. The 'cascading' refers to how styles can inherit and override each other.

question:
Property to change text color:
A. color
B. text-color
C. font-color
D. text-style
answer: A. color - The 'color' property sets the foreground color (text color) of an element.

question:
Select all

elements: A. #p B. .p C. p D. all(p)
answer: C. p - To select all elements of a type, use the element name directly. #p selects an element with id='p', and .p selects elements with class='p'.

question:
CSS Box Model describes:
A. A design pattern
B. Content, padding, border, margin
C. 3D rendering
D. Responsive framework
answer: B. Content, padding, border, margin - The CSS Box Model describes how elements are rendered, consisting of content, padding (space inside), border, and margin (space outside).

question:
Property controlling spacing between elements:
A. space
B. margin
C. padding
D. gap
answer: B. margin - Margin controls the space outside an element's border, creating spacing between elements. Padding controls space inside the border.

question:
Purpose of media queries:
A. Query DB for styles
B. Apply styles for different screens
C. Import styles
D. Animate properties
answer: B. Apply styles for different screens - Media queries allow you to apply CSS styles conditionally based on device characteristics like screen width, enabling responsive design.

question:
Correct variable declaration:
A. variable x = 5
B. var x = 5
C. let x = 5
D. Both B and C
answer: D. Both B and C - Both 'var' and 'let' are valid ways to declare variables in JavaScript. 'let' is preferred in modern JavaScript for block scoping.

question:
typeof [] returns:
A. "array"
B. "object"
C. "list"
D. "undefined"
answer: B. "object" - In JavaScript, arrays are a type of object, so typeof [] returns 'object'. Use Array.isArray() to check if something is specifically an array.

question:
Add an element to end of array:
A. arr.push(el)
B. arr.add(el)
C. arr.append(el)
D. arr.insert(el)
answer: A. arr.push(el) - The push() method adds one or more elements to the end of an array and returns the new length of the array.

question:
Promise used for:
A. Security
B. Async operations
C. Bug-free code
D. Performance
answer: B. Async operations - Promises are used to handle asynchronous operations in JavaScript, providing a cleaner way to work with async code than callbacks.

question:
JSON.parse():
A. Converts object to JSON string
B. Parses JSON string  JS object
C. Validates JSON
D. Creates JSON file
answer: B. Parses JSON string  JS object - JSON.parse() converts a JSON string into a JavaScript object. JSON.stringify() does the opposite (object to string).

question:
Purpose of TypeScript:
A. Replace JS
B. Add static typing
C. Improve performance
D. Simplify syntax
answer: B. Add static typing - TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript that adds static type checking, helping catch errors during development and improving code quality.

question:
Retrieve data:
A. GET
B. SELECT
C. RETRIEVE
D. FETCH
answer: B. SELECT - The SELECT statement is used in SQL to retrieve data from a database table. GET is an HTTP method, not a SQL command.

question:
Primary key:
A. First column
B. Unique identifier
C. Most important table
D. Foreign table ref
answer: B. Unique identifier - A primary key is a column (or set of columns) that uniquely identifies each row in a table. It must be unique and cannot be null.

question:
Clause to filter records:
A. FILTER
B. WHERE
C. HAVING
D. CONDITION
answer: B. WHERE - The WHERE clause filters rows based on specified conditions. HAVING is similar but used with GROUP BY to filter grouped results.

question:
JOIN is used to:
A. Combine rows from two/more tables
B. Join databases
C. Combine columns
D. Join SQL with other languages
answer: A. Combine rows from two/more tables - JOIN operations combine rows from multiple tables based on a related column, allowing you to query data across tables.

question:
Hatch is for:
A. Frontend
B. Python project management/packaging
C. Migrations
D. API testing
answer: B. Python project management/packaging - Hatch is a modern Python project management tool that helps with packaging, dependency management, and project setup.

question:
Command to init Hatch project:
A. hatch new
B. hatch init
C. hatch create
D. hatch start
answer: A. hatch new - The 'hatch new' command creates a new Hatch project with the proper structure and configuration files.

question:
FastAPI is built for:
A. JS
B. Python
C. Java
D. Ruby
answer: B. Python - FastAPI is a modern, fast web framework for building APIs with Python, based on standard Python type hints.

question:
Key FastAPI feature:
A. Automatic API documentation
B. Built-in ORM
C. SSR
D. Microservices orchestration
answer: A. Automatic API documentation - FastAPI automatically generates interactive API documentation (Swagger UI) based on your code, making it easy to test and understand APIs.

question:
FastAPI request validation:
A. Manual
B. Pydantic models
C. External libs only
D. Not supported
answer: B. Pydantic models - FastAPI uses Pydantic models for automatic request validation, serialization, and documentation based on Python type hints.

question:
Dependency injection used to:
A. Reduce duplication
B. Manage DB connections
C. Share objects
D. All of the above
answer: D. All of the above - Dependency injection in FastAPI helps reduce code duplication, manage shared resources like database connections, and share objects across endpoints.

question:
JSX is:
A. DB query language
B. JS extension with HTML-like syntax
C. Styling framework
D. Testing library
answer: B. JS extension with HTML-like syntax - JSX (JavaScript XML) is a syntax extension that allows you to write HTML-like code in JavaScript, used primarily with React.

question:
React component is:
A. CSS file
B. JS function/class returning UI
C. HTML template
D. Bundler config
answer: B. JS function/class returning UI - A React component is a JavaScript function or class that returns JSX (UI elements), making it reusable and composable.

question:
Hook for state:
A. useStatus
B. useState
C. useMemory
D. useData
answer: B. useState - The useState hook is used to add state to functional components in React, allowing components to manage and update their own data.

question:
useEffect used for:
A. Animations
B. Side effects
C. Modify props
D. Rendering performance
answer: B. Side effects - The useEffect hook handles side effects in React components, such as data fetching, subscriptions, or manually changing the DOM.

question:
Pass data parent  child:
A. Global vars
B. Props
C. Context only
D. Modify DOM
answer: B. Props - Props (properties) are the primary way to pass data from parent components to child components in React.

question:
Virtual DOM:
A. Separate DOM for testing
B. Lightweight DOM copy
C. 3D DOM
D. DOM alternative
answer: B. Lightweight DOM copy - The Virtual DOM is a lightweight JavaScript representation of the real DOM that React uses to efficiently update the UI by comparing changes.

question:
ShadCN is:
A. CSS framework
B. UI library for React
C. Accessible customizable UI components
D. Animation library
answer: C. Accessible customizable UI components - ShadCN is a collection of accessible, customizable UI components built with React and Tailwind CSS that you can copy into your project.

question:
How are ShadCN components installed?
A. npm install
B. CLI that copies components
C. CDN
D. Plugin system
answer: B. CLI that copies components - ShadCN components are installed via CLI, which copies the component source code directly into your project, giving you full control to customize them.

question:
ShadCN uses:
A. CSS Modules
B. Styled Components
C. Tailwind CSS
D. Emotion
answer: C. Tailwind CSS - ShadCN components are built using Tailwind CSS for styling, providing utility-first CSS classes.

question:
Next.js is:
A. State library
B. React framework with SSR
C. CSS preprocessor
D. Testing framework
answer: B. React framework with SSR - Next.js is a React framework that provides server-side rendering (SSR), static site generation, and other features for building production-ready applications.

question:
How to create a new page in App Router?
A. New HTML file
B. Add to routes.config.js
C. Create page.js inside app/ subfolder
D. Use createPage()
answer: C. Create page.js inside app/ subfolder - In Next.js 13+ App Router, you create pages by adding a page.js (or page.tsx) file inside a folder within the app/ directory.

question:
getServerSideProps:
A. Client-side fetching
B. Fetch at request time on server
C. Define server routes
D. Configure server
answer: B. Fetch at request time on server - getServerSideProps is a Next.js function that runs on the server for each request, allowing you to fetch data before rendering the page.

question:
Difference between pages/ and app/ in Next.js 13+:
A. pages/ deprecated
B. app/ uses App Router + RSC
C. pages/ supports API routes; app/ doesn't
D. No difference
answer: B. app/ uses App Router + RSC - The app/ directory (App Router) is the new routing system in Next.js 13+ with React Server Components (RSC), while pages/ uses the Pages Router. Both are supported.

question:
Docker is:
A. Language
B. Containerization platform
C. DBMS
D. Hosting service
answer: B. Containerization platform - Docker is a platform that uses containerization to package applications and their dependencies into lightweight, portable containers.

question:
Docker container:
A. Physical storage
B. Lightweight standalone executable package
C. VM
D. Build tool
answer: B. Lightweight standalone executable package - A Docker container is a lightweight, standalone, executable package that includes everything needed to run an application.

question:
File that defines Docker build:
A. docker.json
B. container.yaml
C. Dockerfile
D. docker-config.js
answer: C. Dockerfile - The Dockerfile contains instructions for building a Docker image, specifying the base image, dependencies, and commands to run.

question:
Command to run a container:
A. docker start
B. docker execute
C. docker run
D. docker container
answer: C. docker run - The 'docker run' command creates and starts a new container from an image. 'docker start' starts an existing stopped container.

question:
GitHub Actions used for:
A. Debugging
B. Automating workflows (CI/CD)
C. Managing repos
D. Documentation
answer: B. Automating workflows (CI/CD) - GitHub Actions is a CI/CD platform that automates workflows like building, testing, and deploying code directly from GitHub repositories.

question:
Where are workflow files stored?
A. Root directory
B. .github/workflows
C. .actions
D. .workflows
answer: B. .github/workflows - GitHub Actions workflow files are stored in the .github/workflows directory and are written in YAML format.

question:
What triggers a workflow?
A. Manual only
B. Commits only
C. Pushes, PRs, schedules
D. When issues are created
answer: C. Pushes, PRs, schedules - GitHub Actions workflows can be triggered by various events including pushes, pull requests, scheduled times, manual triggers, and many other GitHub events.

question:
What Git command shows commit history?
A. git history
B. git log
C. git show --all
D. git commits
answer: B. git log - The 'git log' command displays the commit history, showing commits in reverse chronological order with their messages, authors, and dates.

question:
Which command stages changes for a specific file?
A. git add [filename]
B. git stage [filename]
C. git commit [filename]
D. git update [filename]
answer: A. git add [filename] - The 'git add' command stages changes, preparing them to be committed. You can stage specific files or use 'git add .' for all changes.

question:
What is a Git branch?
A. A separate version of code diverging from the main line
B. A collection of repositories
C. A type of remote repo
D. A GitHub project management feature
answer: A. A separate version of code diverging from the main line - A Git branch is a separate line of development that allows you to work on features or fixes independently from the main codebase.

question:
TDD stands for:
A. Technical Design Document
B. Test-Driven Development
C. Technical Debt Demolition
D. Testing & Documentation Development
answer: B. Test-Driven Development - TDD is a software development approach where you write tests before writing the code, following the Red-Green-Refactor cycle.

question:
In project management, what is a sprint?
A. A quick meeting
B. A time-boxed work period
C. A rapid coding session
D. Task prioritization method
answer: B. A time-boxed work period - A sprint is a fixed time period (usually 1-4 weeks) in Agile/Scrum methodology where a team works to complete a set of tasks.

question:
SQL clause used to sort results:
A. SORT BY
B. ORDER BY
C. ARRANGE BY
D. GROUP BY
answer: B. ORDER BY - The ORDER BY clause sorts the result set by one or more columns, either ascending (ASC) or descending (DESC).

question:
Purpose of SQL UPDATE:
A. Create new tables
B. Add new records
C. Modify existing records
D. Delete records
answer: C. Modify existing records - The UPDATE statement modifies existing data in a table. Use INSERT to add new records and DELETE to remove records.

question:
Primary purpose of an API:
A. Create UI
B. Define how software components interact
C. Style web pages
D. Secure apps
answer: B. Define how software components interact - An API (Application Programming Interface) defines how different software components should interact and communicate with each other.

question:
Which HTTP method is idempotent?
A. POST
B. GET
C. PATCH
D. DELETE
answer: B. GET - GET is idempotent, meaning making the same request multiple times produces the same result. POST is not idempotent, and DELETE and PATCH can be idempotent depending on implementation.

question:
Which is NOT a valid JSON type?
A. string
B. number
C. function
D. null
answer: C. function - JSON supports string, number, boolean, null, object, and array types. Functions are not supported in JSON.

question:
FastAPI primarily helps with:
A. Frontend development
B. Building high-performance APIs
C. Database management
D. Network security
answer: B. Building high-performance APIs - FastAPI is a modern Python web framework designed for building fast, high-performance APIs with automatic documentation and validation.

question:
Purpose of a code formatter:
A. Identify vulnerabilities
B. Apply consistent formatting
C. Optimize performance
D. Generate documentation
answer: B. Apply consistent formatting - Code formatters automatically format code according to style guidelines, ensuring consistency across a codebase (e.g., Prettier, Black, autopep8).

question:
HTML element to create a hyperlink:
A. <link>
B. <a>
C. <href>
D. <hyperlink>
answer: B. <a> - The <a> (anchor) element creates hyperlinks. The href attribute specifies the URL. <link> is used for linking external resources like CSS.

question:
What does <canvas> allow?
A. Responsive layouts
B. Draw graphics via JS
C. Display video
D. Style forms
answer: B. Draw graphics via JS - The <canvas> element provides a drawing surface that can be used with JavaScript to create graphics, animations, and visualizations.

question:
HTML tag for a table row:
A. <tr>
B. <row>
C. <td>
D. <th>
answer: A. <tr> - The <tr> element defines a table row. <td> defines table data cells, and <th> defines table header cells.

question:
Purpose of <header>:
A. Create a heading
B. Define a header for a document/section
C. Container for links only
D. Style top of webpage
answer: B. Define a header for a document/section - The <header> element represents introductory content or navigational aids for its nearest sectioning content.

question:
Create a checkbox:
A. <input type="check">
B. <input type="checkbox">
C. <checkbox>
D. <input type="option">
answer: B. <input type="checkbox"> - Checkboxes are created using the <input> element with type="checkbox". This creates a checkbox that users can select or deselect.

question:
Purpose of <script>:
A. Define client-side scripts
B. Scripted animations
C. Script-based layout
D. Import HTML files
answer: A. Define client-side scripts - The <script> element is used to embed or reference JavaScript code that runs on the client side in the browser.

question:
CSS property controlling space inside an element:
A. margin
B. padding
C. border
D. spacing
answer: B. padding - Padding controls the space between an element's content and its border. Margin controls space outside the border.

question:
Select element with class "header":
A. #header
B. .header
C. @header
D. header
answer: B. .header - The dot (.) is used to select elements by class name. #header would select an element with id="header".

question:
Purpose of Flexbox:
A. Create flexible responsive layouts
B. Animate elements
C. Handle forms
D. Connect databases
answer: A. Create flexible responsive layouts - Flexbox (Flexible Box Layout) is a CSS layout model that makes it easy to create flexible, responsive layouts that adapt to different screen sizes.

question:
Property that changes font:
A. font-type
B. font-style
C. font-family
D. text-font
answer: C. font-family - The font-family property specifies the font (typeface) for text. font-style controls italic/oblique, not the font itself.
A. font-weight: bold; - The font-weight property with value 'bold' makes text bold. You can also use numeric values like 700.

question:
What does z-index control?
A. Transparency
B. Width on z-axis
C. Stacking order
D. Zoom level
answer: C. Stacking order - The z-index property controls the stacking order of positioned elements. Higher values appear in front of lower values.

question:
Correct way to write array:
A. var colors = "red","green"
B. var colors = (1:"red")
C. var colors = ["red","green","blue"]
D. var colors = {red, green}
answer: C. var colors = ["red","green","blue"] - Arrays in JavaScript are created using square brackets [] with elements separated by commas.

question:
Correct conditional:
A. if i = 5 then
B. if i == 5 then
C. if (i == 5)
D. if i = 5
answer: C. if (i == 5) - JavaScript if statements use parentheses around the condition. == is used for comparison, = is for assignment.

question:
Correct function syntax:
A. function = myFunction()
B. function myFunction()
C. function
()
D. def myFunction()
answer: B. function myFunction() - Functions in JavaScript are declared using the function keyword followed by the function name and parentheses. 'def' is Python syntax.

question:
What does "5" + 2 return?
A. 7
B. "52"
C. 52
D. Error
answer: B. "52" - JavaScript performs type coercion. When adding a string and a number, the number is converted to a string, resulting in string concatenation.

question:
map() does what?
A. Creates new array by applying function
B. Modifies original array
C. Filters elements
D. Combines arrays
answer: A. Creates new array by applying function - The map() method creates a new array by calling a function on every element of the original array. It doesn't modify the original array.

question:
TypeScript interface:
A. UI component
B. Defines shape of an object
C. Connects languages
D. API interface
answer: B. Defines shape of an object - TypeScript interfaces define the structure and types of properties that an object must have, providing type checking and IntelliSense support.

question:
Delete data:
A. REMOVE
B. DELETE
C. CLEAR
D. DROP
answer: B. DELETE - The DELETE statement removes rows from a table. DROP removes entire tables or databases, while DELETE removes specific records.

question:
Foreign key:
A. Must be unique
B. Connects to primary key in another table
C. Security feature
D. Encryption key
answer: B. Connects to primary key in another table - A foreign key is a column that references the primary key of another table, establishing a relationship between tables.

question:
Select distinct values:
A. SELECT UNIQUE
B. SELECT DIFFERENT
C. SELECT DISTINCT
D. SELECT SEPARATE
answer: C. SELECT DISTINCT - The DISTINCT keyword eliminates duplicate rows from the result set, returning only unique values.

question:
INNER JOIN returns:
A. Records with matching values
B. All records from left + matching right
C. All from both tables
D. First table only
answer: A. Records with matching values - INNER JOIN returns only rows where there is a match in both tables. LEFT JOIN returns all rows from the left table plus matching rows from the right.

question:
Hatch provides:
A. Version control
B. Environment management
C. Dependency tracking
D. Testing environment
answer: B. Environment management - Hatch provides environment management, allowing you to create isolated Python environments with specific versions and dependencies.

question:
How Hatch handles Python versions:
A. It doesn't
B. Installs versions automatically
C. Creates isolated environments with specific versions
D. Modifies system Python
answer: C. Creates isolated environments with specific versions - Hatch can create isolated environments with specific Python versions, similar to virtualenv but with better project management features.

question:
Key advantage of FastAPI:
A. Only framework that works with Python
B. Superior performance + automatic validation
C. Only REST framework
D. Built-in DB
answer: B. Superior performance + automatic validation - FastAPI offers high performance (comparable to Node.js and Go) and automatic request/response validation using Pydantic models.

question:
How FastAPI generates docs:
A. Manually
B. Doesn't generate
C. Automatically via type hints
D. External tools
answer: C. Automatically via type hints - FastAPI automatically generates interactive API documentation (Swagger UI and ReDoc) based on Python type hints and Pydantic models.

question:
Path parameter is:
A. Folder path config
B. Variable part of URL
C. Request body param
D. Query param
answer: B. Variable part of URL - Path parameters are variables defined in the URL path (e.g., /users/{user_id}) that are extracted and passed to the route handler function.

question:
Purpose of a FastAPI dependency:
A. Install packages
B. Share logic across app
C. External service connection
D. Handle version deps
answer: B. Share logic across app - FastAPI dependencies allow you to share common logic (like database connections, authentication) across multiple endpoints, reducing code duplication.

question:
Main building block of React:
A. Modules
B. Components
C. Functions
D. Classes
answer: B. Components - Components are the main building blocks of React applications. They are reusable pieces of UI that can be composed together to build complex interfaces.

question:
Purpose of props:
A. Store local state
B. Pass data parent  child
C. Handle HTTP
D. Styling
answer: B. Pass data parent  child - Props (properties) are the mechanism for passing data from parent components to child components in React.

question:
Update state in functional component:
A. this.setState()
B. Setter from useState()
C. state.update()
D. Modify directly
answer: B. Setter from useState() - In functional components, useState returns [value, setter]. You call the setter function to update state. Never modify state directly.

question:
Purpose of React Context:
A. Style components
B. Handle forms
C. Pass data without props
D. Create reusable components
answer: C. Pass data without props - React Context allows you to share data across the component tree without passing props down through every level (prop drilling).

question:
useRef used for:
A. Trigger re-renders
B. Mutable variable without re-renders
C. External libraries
D. API fetch
answer: B. Mutable variable without re-renders - useRef returns a mutable ref object that persists across renders. Changing .current doesn't trigger a re-render, useful for DOM references or storing mutable values.

question:
Role of key prop:
A. Required for all props
B. Helps React track changed/added/removed items
C. Defines order of elements
D. Sets CSS
answer: B. Helps React track changed/added/removed items - The key prop helps React identify which items have changed, been added, or removed, enabling efficient updates to the Virtual DOM.

question:
What makes ShadCN different?
A. Only works with React
B. Components are copied into your project
C. Supports SSR only
D. Paid license
answer: B. Components are copied into your project - Unlike npm packages, ShadCN components are copied directly into your codebase, giving you full ownership and customization control.

question:
How does ShadCN handle theming?
A. Inline styles
B. CSS variables in global file
C. No theming
D. JavaScript objects
answer: B. CSS variables in global file - ShadCN uses CSS variables defined in a global CSS file (like globals.css) for theming, making it easy to customize colors and styles.

question:
ShadCN builds on which UI primitive library?
A. Material UI
B. Bootstrap
C. Radix UI
D. Ant Design
answer: C. Radix UI - ShadCN components are built on top of Radix UI primitives, which provide accessible, unstyled components that ShadCN then styles with Tailwind CSS.

question:
Next.js used for:
A. Mobile apps
B. React apps with server-side capabilities
C. DB management
D. Design systems
answer: B. React apps with server-side capabilities - Next.js extends React with server-side rendering, static site generation, API routes, and other production-ready features.

question:
Server-side rendering (SSR):
A. Client-only rendering
B. Server generates HTML per request
C. Using a rendering server
D. Pre-render at build time
answer: B. Server generates HTML per request - SSR means the server generates HTML for each request, which is then sent to the client. This improves SEO and initial load time.

question:
Purpose of Next.js Image component:
A. Display images unoptimized
B. Automatically optimize + size images
C. Create galleries
D. Edit images
answer: B. Automatically optimize + size images - Next.js Image component automatically optimizes images (format, size, lazy loading) to improve performance and reduce bandwidth usage.

question:
Create new Next.js project:
A. npm init next-app
B. npx create-next-app
C. npm install next-app
D. npx next create
answer: B. npx create-next-app - The standard command to create a new Next.js project is 'npx create-next-app [project-name]', which sets up a new Next.js application with all necessary files.

question:
Purpose of Docker volumes:
A. Store images
B. Persistent storage
C. Network between containers
D. Optimize performance
answer: B. Persistent storage - Docker volumes provide persistent storage that survives container deletion, allowing data to persist beyond the container's lifecycle.

question:
List running containers:
A. docker list
B. docker ps
C. docker containers
D. docker show
answer: B. docker ps - The 'docker ps' command lists running containers. Use 'docker ps -a' to see all containers including stopped ones.

question:
Docker Compose used for:
A. Writing Dockerfiles
B. Building images
C. Multi-container apps
D. Managing networks
answer: C. Multi-container apps - Docker Compose is a tool for defining and running multi-container Docker applications using a YAML file to configure services.

question:
Dockerfile instruction for base image:
A. BASE
B. FROM
C. IMAGE
D. USING
answer: B. FROM - The FROM instruction specifies the base image to use for the Docker build. It must be the first instruction in a Dockerfile.

question:
Workflow files are written in:
A. JSON
B. YAML
C. XML
D. JavaScript
answer: B. YAML - GitHub Actions workflow files are written in YAML (YAML Ain't Markup Language) format and stored in .github/workflows/.

question:
What is a GitHub Actions artifact?
A. File created by workflow
B. Repo type
C. Runner
D. Workflow template
answer: A. File created by workflow - Artifacts are files created by a workflow that can be stored and downloaded, such as build outputs, test results, or logs.
D. ${{ env.VAR_NAME }} - In GitHub Actions, environment variables are referenced using the expression syntax ${{ env.VAR_NAME }} or ${{ secrets.VAR_NAME }} for secrets.

question:
What is a Git repository?
A. A folder containing all project files and revision history
B. A backup system for code
C. A collaborative coding platform
D. A version of the code on a remote server
answer: A. A folder containing all project files and revision history - A Git repository is a directory that contains your project files and the entire history of changes tracked by Git.

question:
What does git pull do?
A. Upload local commits to a remote repository
B. Download and integrate changes from a remote repository
C. Compare differences between repositories
D. Create a new branch from the remote repository
answer: B. Download and integrate changes from a remote repository - 'git pull' fetches changes from a remote repository and merges them into your current branch.

question:
What is a pull request in GitHub?
A. A way to fetch changes
B. A request to pull data from an API
C. A way to propose changes and request review/merge
D. A method to download a repository
answer: C. A way to propose changes and request review/merge - A pull request (PR) allows you to propose changes to a repository and request that they be reviewed and merged into the main branch.

question:
Key principle of Test-Driven Development:
A. Write documentation before code
B. Write tests after code
C. Write tests before implementing code
D. Test after entire application is complete
answer: C. Write tests before implementing code - TDD follows the Red-Green-Refactor cycle: write failing tests first, then write code to make them pass, then refactor.

question:
Test that focuses on individual functions/components:
A. Integration tests
B. Unit tests
C. End-to-end tests
D. System tests
answer: B. Unit tests - Unit tests verify that individual functions, methods, or components work correctly in isolation from other parts of the system.

question:
SQL command to create a new table:
A. ADD TABLE
B. CREATE TABLE
C. INSERT TABLE
D. NEW TABLE
answer: B. CREATE TABLE - The CREATE TABLE statement defines a new table with its columns, data types, and constraints.

question:
SQL COUNT() does what?
A. Counts rows matching a condition
B. Sums numeric values
C. Averages column values
D. Counts number of columns
answer: A. Counts rows matching a condition - COUNT() is an aggregate function that returns the number of rows that match a specified condition.

question:
HTTP status indicating a client error:
A. 200
B. 301
C. 404
D. 500
answer: C. 404 - HTTP status codes in the 4xx range indicate client errors. 404 means Not Found. 200 is success, 301 is redirect, and 500 is a server error.

question:
Architectural style for networked applications:
A. OOP
B. MVC
C. REST
D. Microservices
answer: C. REST - REST (Representational State Transfer) is an architectural style for designing networked applications, commonly used for web APIs.

question:
JSON stands for:
A. JavaScript Object Notation
B. Java Standard Object Notation
C. JavaScript Oriented Networking
D. Java Source Object Notation
answer: A. JavaScript Object Notation - JSON is a lightweight data interchange format that is easy for humans to read and write, and easy for machines to parse and generate.

question:
Purpose of Hatch:
A. Frontend build system
B. Python project management
C. JS linting
D. Database migration
answer: B. Python project management - Hatch is a modern Python project management tool that helps with packaging, dependency management, and project setup.

question:
Pre-commit tool is used for:
A. Auto-committing code
B. Running checks before committing
C. Generating commit messages
D. Scheduling commits
answer: B. Running checks before committing - Pre-commit hooks run automated checks (like linting, formatting, tests) before a commit is finalized, helping maintain code quality.

question: HTML tag for an image: A. B. C. D.
answer: A. - The element embeds an image in an HTML document. is used for responsive images, and

question:
Attribute for image alternate text:
A. src
B. alt
C. title
D. desc
answer: B. alt - The alt attribute provides alternative text for images, used by screen readers and displayed when the image cannot be loaded.

question:
Purpose of <section>:
A. Navigation links
B. Define a section in a document
C. Section of form elements
D. CSS-styled section
answer: B. Define a section in a document - The <section> element represents a standalone section of content, typically with a heading, that groups related content together.

question:
Numbered list tag:
A. <nl>
B. <list type="numbered">
C. <ol>
D. <ul>
answer: C. <ol> - The <ol> (ordered list) element creates a numbered list. <ul> creates an unordered (bulleted) list.

question:
What does <iframe> do?
A. Embed another document inline
B. Display images
C. Floating frame
D. Framed page section
answer: A. Embed another document inline - The <iframe> (inline frame) element embeds another HTML page within the current page.

question:
HTML tag used to create a form:
A. <input>
B. <form>
C. <fieldset>
D. <formfield>
answer: B. <form> - The <form> element creates an HTML form for collecting user input. <input> elements go inside the form.
B. h1 {} - To style all elements of a type, use the element selector directly. h1 selects all <h1> elements.

question:
CSS property for text size:
A. text-size
B. font-size
C. text-style
D. font-style
answer: B. font-size - The font-size property controls the size of text. font-style controls italic/oblique, not size.

question:
Purpose of CSS Grid:
A. One-dimensional layouts
B. Two-dimensional grid layouts
C. Add grid lines
D. Grid animations
